Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I was sitting in my van, phone in hand, waiting for the customer to answer. The package I was supposed to deliver had been misplaced at the depot, and now the customer was calling, their tone already tense. I knew I had to be calm, professional, and reassuring, even though I didn’t have good news. At the same time, my daughter’s message popped up on my phone—she’d just started her new job and wanted to share her excitement. She’d sent a photo of her desk, a big smile on her face, and a message: “Can’t wait to tell you all about it, Grandpa!” I felt a tug in my chest. I wanted to call her right away, to be the supportive grandparent she expected, to share in her joy and make her feel heard. But the customer was waiting, and my job demanded my full attention and patience. I stared at the two notifications, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which voice to answer first.
